titleStmt.title: Example entries from the Nxaʔamxcín (Moses) Dictionary Database

publicationStmt.p: Provided as examples to the TEI LingSIG.

sourceDesc.p: University of Victoria Nxaʔamxcín Dictionary Database Project.

encodingDesc.p: This file consists of a pair of multi-morphemic entries, each of which has a hyph which breaks it down into individual morphemes. The hyph contains links to the component monomorphemic entries which are also included here. The links between morphemes (which also occur in the context of cited quotations and cross-references) are encoded using the a private URI scheme with the prefix "m".

Other links using the private URI scheme with the "psn" prefix link to individuals in a personography, and mysterious bibl contents are coded references to sessions with informants. Information on individuals and sessions is not included here.

form.note: The form /hamp/ "fall, fall off, drop" never surfaces as /ham/ in MDK's data; given this; ECH analyzes /p/ as part of the root, rather than as the inchoative marker /-p/.
Is there a word "ham", with a meaning like "fall"?

def.seg: fall off something; be thrown from a horse
he fell off; it dropped (by itself)

entry.note: MDK indicated that the following forms were ungrammatical: *hə́mən EP; EP4.55, *hə́mpm .
MDK listed the form kaRámət S2.5 on his file card with the stem /hamp/. The meaning is not listed, and it is not clear whether R represents /h/ or /ḥ/

pron.note: copies and is suffixed after leftmost CVC in root; never stressed

def.note: occurs in forms with adjectival meanings; sometimes provides distributive/plural meaning or occurs in words with lexicalized meaning
See Willett (2003:242-ff) for discussion of adjectival marking.
def.label: char

def.seg: habitual aspect marker; indicates that a particular action or state is common to, characteristic, or typical of an individual
def.note: often accompanied by augmentative or characteristic reduplication
def.label: hb

quote.seg: dancer; person who dances a lot
someone always begging for food or drink
he wants to eat all the time

form.note: prefixed to root; copies first two root consonants usually with intervening schwa; never stressed

def.note: in nouns refers to plurality; in verbs refers to repeated action, action distributed over time/space, or an increase in intensity
def.label: aug

quote.seg: I put his shoes on him
put pieces on both sides to hold rigid
they are the same; a pair
streaks in the sky at night
smiling down at a littly baby
lay several things down on the ground
get to the edge of a hill
the grass has been tramped down
people making a lot of noise
get tired of (doing) something too regular; do not believe him
spread arms out with bones concealed in hands ready to be guessed
I shook a stick/finger at him
a design like check or plaid ??
I get the best of him; passing each other
they are throwing something at each other
they are boxing; they are hitting each other
they are talking to each other

entry.note: Root entry added based on attested complex forms.

def.note: On his filecards, MDK identified five separate meanings for this suffix. However, he subsequently combined them all into one entry.
def.label: la

quote.seg: mouth of a river on upper side
pick up and store with the mouth
half-way up to the knees in depth
the area below rapids in a river
he is in front of me
I took a liking to it
someone who always wants to insult people
a person with sideburns down beside the ears (or lower)
I stopped him from arguing/quarreling with someone
he got a fat lip (by being hit)
get a split lip (from being hit)
ramble on when about to die
say something unintended; get mixed up in what saying
new dancer: first time singing (in Chinook dance)
land on the shore in a boat
finish eating; a lot of whiskers
a pole crosswise in a creek
a pole crosswise in a creek
sit on the edge of a river
sit on the edge of a river
I pulled it up (from a canyon, up a river bank)

def.note: In addition to his file card for this lexical suffix, MDK listed the extended senses of =anaʔ "over, on top of" on a separate card in the affix file. Therefore, I have maintained two separate entries for this suffix.
def.label: la

quote.seg: fawn in fall with buttons of horns
bulge on the side of the face
he got hit on the ear
a person with sideburns down beside the ears (or lower)
camas beds in the low ridges just north of the flats where US 2 joins the Coulee Highway
Black Canyon Creek; streams coming into main creek

def.note: Is it possible to figure out the meaning of this suffix from the words it occurs in?
def.label: la
